text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is an [mathjaxinline]m\times n[/mathjaxinline] matrix which has at least one free variable. Can we conclude that the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] do not span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ m[/mathjaxinline]?

Suppose [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is an [mathjaxinline]n\times n[/mathjaxinline] matrix which has at least one free variable. Can we conclude that the columns of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] do not span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline]?

solution.font: For the first question, we cannot make that conclusion, since we are not told the matrix is square. For instance, [mathjaxinline]\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] has a free variable, but its columns span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline]. For the second question, we know the matrix is square, so the Invertible Matrix Theorem applies. Since [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] has a free variable, we can conclude that none of the conditions in the Invertible Matrix Theorem are true. In particular, its columns do not span [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^ n[/mathjaxinline].
